1.text: My soul hath been weary of my life, I leave off my talking to myself, I speak in the bitterness of my soul.

2.text: I say unto God, ‘Do not condemn me, Let me know why Thou dost strive with me.

3.text: Is it good for Thee that Thou dost oppress? That Thou despisest the labour of Thy hands, And on the counsel of the wicked hast shone?

4.text: Eyes of flesh hast Thou? As man seeth—seest Thou?

5.text: As the days of man are Thy days? Thy years as the days of a man?

6.text: That Thou inquirest for mine iniquity, And for my sin seekest?

7.text: For Thou knowest that I am not wicked, And there is no deliverer from Thy hand.

8.text: Thy hands have taken pains about me, And they make me together round about, And Thou swallowest me up!

9.text: Remember, I pray Thee, That as clay Thou hast made me, And unto dust Thou dost bring me back.

10.text: Dost Thou not as milk pour me out? And as cheese curdle me?

11.text: Skin and flesh Thou dost put on me, And with bones and sinews dost fence me.

12.text: Life and kindness Thou hast done with me. And Thy inspection hath preserved my spirit.

13.text: And these Thou hast laid up in Thy heart, I have known that this is with Thee.

14.text: If I sinned, then Thou hast observed me, And from mine iniquity dost not acquit me,

15.text: If I have done wickedly—woe to me, And righteously—I lift not up my head, Full of shame—then see my affliction,

16.text: And it riseth—as a lion Thou huntest me. And Thou turnest back—Thou shewest Thyself wonderful in me.

17.text: Thou renewest Thy witnesses against me, And dost multiply Thine anger with me, Changes and warfare are with me.

18.text: And why from the womb Hast Thou brought me forth? I expire, and the eye doth not see me.

19.text: As I had not been, I am, From the belly to the grave I am brought,

20.text: Are not my days few? Cease then, and put from me, And I brighten up a little,

21.text: Before I go, and return not, Unto a land of darkness and death-shade,

22.text: A land of obscurity as thick darkness, Death-shade—and no order, And the shining is as thick darkness.’
